newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Asian experts urge worldwide ban on landmines.
newsitem.headline: Asian experts urge worldwide ban on landmines.

text.p: Asian military experts on Wednesday backed the adoption of an international ban on landmines -- the world's "hidden killers" -- and urged Asian nations to stop producing, stockpiling and exporting them.

In a declaration ending a three-day meeting in Manila, experts from 18 countries called on the Asian Development Bank and other institutions to help finance a massive operation to clear an estimated 100 million landmines planted in 64 countries.
It did not name the states that continue to produce the weapon but a conference official said China and Russia were among them.
Countries most affected by landmines included Afghanistan, Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam, the statement said.

Indiscriminate of time, place and target, they are the world's "hidden killers," Peter Herby, legal adviser of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), which organised the meeting, told the closing session.
Herby cited the case of a three-year-old Cambodian girl whom an ICRC worker found chained to a tree near her house and thought it was the most inhuman thing a mother could do to her child.
The worker realised later "it was the most loving thing the mother could do for her" because they lived next to a minefield.
The mother had gone out to look for firewood but stepped on a landmine and never returned, Herby said.
"The global scourge of anti-personnel landmines is unacceptable and must be stopped," the declaration said. "The appalling consequences of (their) use...have far outweighed their military utility."
The declaration called on all Asian states to take part in upcoming negotiations in Oslo aimed at concluding a treaty banning the weapon worldwide by December.
